title: What is a matter wave? What is its physical significance? What type of wave is it? - Quora

response.answer_text: All quanta (i.e. all “particles”) are waves, or disturbances, in a fundamental quantum field. For example, a photon is a wave in the universal electromagnetic field, and an electron is a wave in the universal electron positron field. A material quantum, such as an electron, quark, proton, or atom, is a “matter wave” in a corresponding universal quantum field (the e-p field, a quark field, etc.). For more details, see: • my non-technical book Tales of the Quantum (Oxford University Press, 2017). • “There are no particles, there are only fields,” Am. J. Phys., Vol. 81, p. 211-233 (Mar. 2013). • "Electrons as field quanta," Am. J. of Phys., Vol. 73, p. 630 (July 2005).

Over the course of our evolution we have built up a set of concepts and ideas that help us navigate the world. In particular, we have concepts of “point particles” and “waves.” Quantum theory involves the world of the very small, which is far outside our day-to-day intuition and experience. Under certain conditions, quantum entities behave like particles, and under other conditions they behave like waves. We normally think of matter as consisting of particles, and things like light, sound, and so on consisting of waves. Here we can think of matter as “anything that has mass.” Most of the time, in our day-to-day experience, matter does behave like point particles and light does behave like waves. However ultimately these things are built of quantum entities, which can behave like either depending on the conditions you’re created. A matter wave is simply a collection of matter (with mass) that is currently exhibiting wave-like attributes, because you’ve set up experimental conditions that make those attributes manifest.
